required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sympathetic-Somatomotor Coupling in Human Spinal Cord Injury

brief_summary.textblock:
Significance: The long term objective of this study is to improve physical therapy and fitness programs in people with spinal cord injury. The results of the study will demonstrate the importance of matching blood flow to a muscle with exercise of that same muscle.
Scientific Objective: The objective of the study is to measure how the body regulates bloodflow to a muscle during exercise. We intend to study these effects by triggering blood flow changes during movement, and measuring bloodflow changes during exercise in people with spinal cord injury. We will also look at the long term effects of different exercise programs on bloodflow during exercise.
Study Populations: This study will involve people with partial spinal cord injury and age and sex matched controls without injury.
Specific Aims: Aim 1 will be to measure bloodflow during exercise of the legs (below the injury). This aim will examine the control of bloodflow and muscle contractions and how it changes after spinal cord injury. In Aim 2, we will identify changes in the bloodflow during exercise of the arms (above the spinal injury). Aim 3 will then look at changes in bloodflow during exercise after training. Three different eight week exercise training programs will be tested including 1) upper body ergometry, 2) treadmill training with exertion level matched to the upper body ergometry and 3) treadmill training with heart rate matched to an initial test of upper body ergometry.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: Subject will be tested with doppler ultrasonography immediately pre and post sympathetic stressor. Testing sessions will take anywhere between 3-6 hours.

secondary_outcome.description: Graded treadmill exercise test will be tested at multiple intervals pre and post training paradigms.
Heart rate will be tested continuously during sympathetic stressors and at multiple intervals pre and post training paradigms with a Finapres.
Knee torque will be tested with the Biodex both pre and post sympathetic stressors.
Tendon tap reflexes will be tested during one day testing pre and post sympathetic stressors.

arm_group.arm_group_label: One day testing of sympathetic nervous system
arm_group.description: Aim 1 will be to measure bloodflow during exercise of the legs (below the injury). This aim will examine the control of bloodflow and muscle contractions and how it changes after spinal cord injury.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Upper body ergometry effects on sympathetic measures in SCI.
arm_group.description: Upper body ergometry: Aim 2, we will identify changes in the bloodflow during exercise of the arms (above the spinal injury).

arm_group.arm_group_label: Effects of long term training on sympathetic measures in SCI
arm_group.description: Aim 3 will then look at changes in bloodflow during exercise after training. Three different eight week exercise training programs will be tested including 1) upper body ergometry, 2) treadmill training with exertion level matched to the upper body ergometry and 3) treadmill training with heart rate matched to an initial test of upper body ergometry.

intervention.description: Training will be provided during scheduled 1 hr sessions 3-5X per week. Following graded UBE testing (described below), subjects will be asked to work at an rating of perceived exertion (RPE) of 16-17 while cycling an ergometer (Reck Motomed, Betzenweiler, Germany) at 60-70 rpm with resistance graded according to patient tolerance/responses while heart rate is monitored. Power (W) will be increased 5-10 W as tolerated to maintain 16-17 RPE throughout training.
intervention.arm_group_label: Upper body ergometry effects on sympathetic measures in SCI.

intervention.description: Matched Intensity Treadmill Training: Training will be provided during scheduled 1 hr sessions 3-5X per week. Treadmill training will be performed at intensities approaching 85% of maximum predicted heart rate and recommended by the American College of Sports Medicine. Training intensity will be monitored during the training session, maintaining an RPE score similar to UBE training (16-17). Matched Heart Rate Treadmill Training: Similar treadmill training paradigms as described above will be performed during Matched Heart Rate Training on the treadmill. Following graded testing with UBE (see below) the heart rate measured during an RPE of 16-17 during UBE testing will be utilized as the initial goal for treadmill walking. The matched heart rate will normalize cardiovascular stress between UBE and treadmill stepping. Weight support and robotic or therapist assistance will be utilized as described above.
intervention.arm_group_label: Effects of long term training on sympathetic measures in SCI

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- incomplete SCI
- subjects will be over age 18
- to fit in the apparatus and to assure a mature gait pattern
- at least 6 months post injury, and medically stable with an incomplete lesion between levels T1-T10
- lower extremity motor score of 10 or greater
- presence of intact stretch reflexes, detected clinically
- no previous history or evidence of peripheral nerve damage in the lower extremities
- Subjects must be able to step on a treadmill with no more than 40% body weight support.
Healthy controls will be age and sex matched to the subjects with spinal cord injury.
Exclusion Criteria:
- unhealed decubiti,
- bladder or other infection
- severe contracture or osteoporosis
- heterotopic ossification
- cardiac arrhythmia
- inability to give informed consent
- an episode of autonomic dysreflexia in the past year
- use of spasticity or cardiovascular medications (e.g. baclofen)
